column1: Vulvar cancer is cancer that starts in the vulva.
In some cases, vulvar cancer starts on the clitoris or in glands on the sides of the vagina opening.
Most vulvar cancers begin in skin cells called squamous cells.
Other vulvar cancers are: - Adenocarcinoma - Basal cell carcinoma - Melanoma - Sarcoma Vulvar cancer is rare.
Most cases of VIN, though, never lead to cancer.
Women with this condition will often have itching around the vagina for years.

Other skin changes that may occur around the vulva: - Mole or freckle, which may be pink, red, white, or gray - Skin thickening or lump - Skin sore (ulcer) Other symptoms: - Pain or burning with urination - Pain with intercourse - Unusual odor Some women with vulvar cancer have no symptoms.
The following tests are used to diagnose vulvar cancer: - Biopsy - CT scan or MRI of the pelvis to look for cancer spread - Pelvic examination to look for any skin changes
Radiation, with or without chemotherapy, may be used to treat advanced tumors or vulvar cancer that comes back.
Call your health care provider if you have any of these symptoms for more than 2 weeks: - Local irritation - Skin color change - Sore on the vulva
This includes using condoms to protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
The vaccine is approved to prevent cervical cancer and genital warts.
The vaccine is given to young girls before they become sexually active, and to adolescents and women up to age 26.
Routine pelvic exams can help diagnose vulvar cancer at an earlier stage.
